div.p: Mr. Hanſon reads—'Tis very hard to give a true account.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Read it to your ſelf if you will, and tell us the Subſtance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: If my words may not turn to the prejudice of my Lord Count Conningsmark, but this is the ſubſtance of the thing; my Lord Count Conningsmark did tell me in familiar Diſcourſe, that Eſquire Thynne had ſpoken ſome reflecting Words upon him; he did deſire to know if he did call him to account, whether in this caſe the Laws of England might not go contrary to his Deſign in his Pretenſions, that he might have upon my Lady Ogle. And in that familiar Diſcourſe, he ſeemed to think that Monfieur Lienburgh could give him advice. In a little while afterwards, I was paying my reſpects to the Envoy, and reflecting upon the Counts Converſation, I ſpoke to him about this buſineſs, and his anſwer was this; he told me, that if he ſhould meddle with Mr. Thynne, he would have no good living in England: But as to the particular Queſtion, what the Conſequence of the Law might be, he did not know, but inquire and tell me, but I never asked him any Queſtion about it afterwards. And if my Converſation with this Count, or with Monſieur Lienburgh, ſhould turn to the Count's prejudice, I ſhould be anſwerable for it to God and my own Conſcience, all the dayes of my Life. I deſire Mr. Thynne's blood might be revenged, but I deſire alſo, that innocent Blood may be ſpared.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Win.
sp.p: Pray Sir, will you look upon that Paper, you ſigned it.

sp.speaker: L. C J. North.
sp.p: Only to recollect your Memory.

p.hi: Then he was ſhew'd his Examination before the Council.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now you have read it over, that there is under your own hand, do you now again deliver the ſubſtance of your diſcourſe you had with Count Conningſmark as you will ſtand by it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I ſee that there are expreſſions in this Paper.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Speak not what is in that Paper, but what diſcourſe (as near as you can) you had with Count Conningſmark.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: My Diſcourſe with Count Conningſmark was this; in a familiar Diſcourſe amongſt other things, he ſpoke, that he heard Eſq Thynne had affronted him, I don't know upon what Subject, but I believe it was words reflecting upon him and his Horſe; he did not tell me that he deſired me to go, nor did he give me any poſitive charge to go to the Swediſh Envoy, but by the diſcourſe I had with him, I did underſtand that he was deſirous to have his advice, I thought his inclinations were, that I ſhould go and ask his advice; I did not go on purpoſe to do the Meſſage, nor did I receive any order that can be called a Meſſage in my Life, to my remembrance; but when I came to pay my reſpects in a familiar Diſcourſe, I did propoſe this to the Envoy; what might be the Conſequence, if the Count ſhould call Mr. Thynne to account; and he told me the ſame Anſwer that I have already told you. Now this I deſire only to conſider, that it was ſpoken in divers Languages; and if a man ſhould write down my Expreſſions now, as they came from me, they would upon reading perhaps, appear not ſo well; ſo if theſe Expreſſions of mine ſhould turn to Count Conningsmark's prejudice, as that I ſhould Swear that this Phraſe of killing or duelling was uſed, or that ever Count Conningsmark told me that he reſolved to call, or that he would call him to an account, I might do him wrong perhaps, but if he ſhould call him to account, what might be the Conſequence of it.

sp.speaker: Sir. Fran. Win.
sp.p: I would not intangle you, but only I would ſeek after the Truth. I do not ask you poſitively, whether he did bid you go to ask advice of the Swediſh Envoy, that he did reſolve ſo and ſo; but did he diſcourſe it thus, if he ſhould Duel him or Fight him.?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: As I am before God Almighty, I cannot ſay I heard ſuch Expreſſions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray Sir, you confeſs you acquainted the Envoy with it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Did you bring the Envoy's Anſwer to the Gent. or no?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: If I ſhould be upon the Goſpel, I am ſure I cannot exactly tell, what was the Expreſſion.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: What was it that you diſcerned he doubted, if he did call Mr. Thynne to account?

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Win.
sp.p: He ſpoke in relation to a Marriage, pray what was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What did that if relate to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: If he ſhould ask him ſatisfaction about it, having heard that he had ſpoken abuſive words of him?

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Win.
sp.p: What then was to follow?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: If he ſhould call him to account, then how the Laws of England might do in this Point?

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: To the Count.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What ſhould befall him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Whether the Law ſhould be contrary to him in the Deſign and Propoſals h • might have, concerning the Young Counteſs of Ogle.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Well, I ſee you will give no reaſonable anſwer to that; but now, when came the Polander over into England?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I cannot ſay poſitively I can tell when he came.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: But when did you ſee him firſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p:
Upon the Friday he came and asked me for the Count at Monſieur Fauberts Academy. Now the young Count Conningsmark's Chamber and mine joyns
together, next to one another, and there came a man with him, I do not know his name, but if I ſee the man I know him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: You ſay the Polander came over on Friday?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: He came to me on Friday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: And he came to you to the French Academy, to enquire for Count Conningsmark?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, he did ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Had he any Letters?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, he had two Letters.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: From whom and to whom?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I asked him if he had any Letter for Count Conningsmark, and he ſaid no; but he told me he had two Letters, and the one was to the Count's Secretary, and the other was to the Count's Steward in London. So I gave him back his Letters, and asked him whence he came; he told me, he was juſt come into England. I asked him, whether he had been a great while at Sea, and he told me, yes; and that it was Stormy, and he had like to have been caſt away; ſaid I, I hear you are expected therefore; have you paid your Lodging; no, ſaid he; then ſaid I, go and pay your Lodging, and come to me in the Morning early.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Win.
sp.p: You ſay you heard he was expected, pray who expected him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: The Count; for he had ſpoken formerly twice of the Polander, and in the great Storm thought he had been drowned. To the beſt of my remembrance, I have heard the Count ſpeak twice of this Polander.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Win.
sp.p: Of this man?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe it is the ſame.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Win.
sp.p: You ſay you ſaw him on Friday?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: When did he ſpeak of the ſtormy Weather? And that he was afraid the Polander might miſcarry?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: About twelve or thirteen dayes before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Now ſay as hear as you can what the Count ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: He ſaid the Polander was a mighty able man, and underſtood horſes, and the Count had a mind to buy Engliſh Horſes, and intended to have had this Polander as a Groom to dreſs them after the German way, and no man was abler than the Polander to do it; and when he ſpoke of it, I went once to the Change, and inquired whether the Ship was loſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Win.
sp.p: By whoſe Directions did you go to inquire whether the Ship were loſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I had no Direction, but only Count Conningsmark's ſpeaking about it.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Win.
sp.p: He ſeemed to be concerned at it, did he?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, he was afraid that the Polander would be drowned.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: You ſay you directed him to clear his Quarters?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, I did ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Did you ſee him again the next day?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, he came the next day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was he the next day in Company with the Count or no?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I brought him to the Count.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Win.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: It was a little before Noon; becauſe I went the back way, and I left him at the Counts Lodging.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Did you leave him with the Count?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray, as long as you were there, what paſſed between the Count and the Polander?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I remember very well what paſſed between the Count and him, for I have thought of it. He ſpoke to him, and called him thou, as to his Servant, and asked him, where he had been all the while, and he anſwered he had been at Sea, toſſed up and down.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Withins.
sp.p: Pray what directions had you given about a Sword for that Polander?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I went to the Counts Lodgings, and being deſired by him to ſtay, I deſired he would excuſe me, for I could not ſtay, becauſe I was to go about another Buſineſs; he told me the Fellow was all naked, and he had no man to ſend to buy him a Riding-Coat; I told him I would very willingly and heartily do it. And after I had dined, I went to an Houſe near the Hay-market, and bought a Riding-Coat, and brought the Riding-Coat to the Counts Lodgings. I delivered it to the Count. Then the Count told me his Man had never a Sword, and I asked him how much his Lordſhip would pleaſe to beſtow on a Sword, he told me a matter of 10s. or thereabouts; I told him I did not know where I ſhould get ſuch a Sword, nor how to ſend for it, becauſe I was to meet his Brother, but I withal ſaid, it is no matter for that, I will take care you ſhall have it; this Evening I went into St. Martins-Lane, but could not find ever a Sword worth a Groat. Then I went as far as Charing-Croſs to a Cutler whom I knew, ſo I told him, Sir, ſaid I, I have a Commiſſion to beſtow 10 s. on a Sword for a Servant, therefore ſaid I, I leave it to your diſcretion, uſe my Friend well, and uſe your ſelf favourably too. I asked him when I ſhould have the Sword, he told me in the Evening; I told him I would call for it when I came from the Play, where I was to be with the Counts Brother. When I came back with the young Count Conningſmark from the Play I called for the Sword, but he told me it was not ready. I ſeemed to be a little angry, and told him that it was ſtrange, a Gentleman could not get a little Sword got ready for him in an whole Afternoon. Well, Sir, ſaid he, pray do not be impatient, I will ſend you the Sword, and afterwards he ſent it to the Academy, and I afterwards ſent the Sword to Count Conningſmarks Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray had you this Direction for the Sword, after you had brought the Polander to the Count, or before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Count Conningſmark did never give me any direction or charge to buy a Sword for him, but I did offer my Service if he pleaſed, becauſe he ſaid, he had no body to ſend.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Sir, You do not know the Queſtion, or you won't apprehend it; pray when had you this direction from the Count to buy this Sword?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: On Saturday in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: When was it you brought the Polander to the Count?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: In the morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Pray let me ask you another Queſtion, when was it you firſt heard Mr. Thynne was kill'd?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I heard it I believe about eight a Clock in the evening on Sunday.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Had you any Diſcourſe with the Count about the Murder?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, I had.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Pray tell what that Diſcourſe was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I was at Whitehall till ten of the Clock, and then I went to the Count; but I deſire this may not be taken as an extraordinary Viſit, becauſe I uſed to go to him on the Sundays in the Evenings, and thoſe 3 ſundays before he was taken, I uſed to come to him in the Evening, after I had been at Whitehall. When I came into his Lodgings, I found him in his Night-cap, and Night-gown; he asked me what News, I told him I could tell him great News, and that was of the killing of Eſq Thynne, who was Shot in his Coach; The Embaſſador of Savoy had told me all that he had heard about it, and I told it him. After I had ſpoken of this Buſineſs, he asked me where his Brother was; I told him, his Brother was at the Duke of Richmonds. And after ſome Diſcourſe I went away.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: When you told him of the Murder of Mr. Thynne, did he make no Anſwer, nor ſay any thing about it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: He did not make me any Anſwer, by which I could conclude that Count Conningſmark was any way concerned in the Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Withins.
sp.p: Pray Sir, I ask you upon your Oath, the Count is a man of great Quality himſelf; When you told him of ſuch an horrid Murder, what, did he ſay nothing about it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: He asked me ſeveral Queſtions, what the People did ſay, but I would not make any miſtake.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Tell all he ſaid Sir about it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I told him the greateſt News I heard was, the killing of Mr. Thynne; and I told him who brought the News, and I told him the Court was heartily angry at it, that ſuch an Accident ſhould happen, and I ſaid it was an Italian trick, not uſed in England.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: What ſaid he then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray do you remember what he ſaid?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: What I have Anſwered now. He made me ſuch Queſtions upon this ſtory as I have told you.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: Let him explain himſelf, pray as near as you can, relate what Diſcourſe you had with Count Conningſmark, that Sunday night after you came to him and told him of the Murder.

sp.speaker: Sir. Fra. Winn.
sp.p: What did he ſay to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I will tell you my Lord; the Count was ſurprized as every man would be to hear of ſo ſad an Accident, and ſo the Count asked me what the People ſaid, ſo I told him what I heard at Whitehall, I cannot call to my memory all the Particulars; but I ſaid the King was heartily ſorry, and all the Court for ſo ſad an Accident, and I muſt wrong my ſelf or Count Conningſmark, if I ſhould undertake to relate exactly what paſſed, for I cannot remember it.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: But you ſaid juſt now, that you told the Count it looked like an Italian Trick, not uſed in England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, I did ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: What did he reply to that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Did he mention any thing of Fortifications to you then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: Yes, he gave me a Plain, or a Draught of a Fortification done with his own Hand, and that was all the diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: So then he diverted the diſcourſe to the buſineſs of Fortification.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: The Evidence is heard, what it is that he ended all the diſcourſe with, ſhewing him a Paper of Fortifications.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: But this he does ſay, He asked him what the people did ſay of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: For my Life I dare not ſay I remember any more than I have told.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, now, will you in French deliver this, for the benefit of thoſe Jury-men that don't underſtand Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: We pray, my Lord, our Interpreter may do it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: When a Man can ſpeak both Languages, he needs no Interpreter, he is his own beſt Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: My Lord, I will tell you why I ask it; there is a great deal of difference, I find, where you examine a man with the Hair, and where you examine him againſt the Hair: where you find it difficult to make a man anſwer, you will pump him with Queſtions, and croſs interrogate him to ſift out the Truth; now if you leave this Man to the interpretation of what he hath ſaid himſelf, he will make a fine Story of it, and we ſhall be never the wiſer.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: You may examine him in French if you will.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: And I underſtand none but Pedlers French.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: The truth of it is, what your Lordſhip ſays, cannot be oppoſed regularly; but I do appeal to your Lordſhip, and all the Judges, and all the Court, whether this man does anſwer like an ingenuous man; you ſee he ſhifts.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: I do not ſee it, nor do I believe any ſee he ſhifts in any thing you ask of him; either he tells you what the Queſtion is, or the reaſon of it; how far that is a Reaſon, is left to the Jury to conſider.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Certainly it can do no hurt to have an Interpreter.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: North. My Lord, if there be two ways to take, 'tis beſt to take that which will give ſatisfaction to all Perſons, let him be asked by the Interpreter, what Queſtions the Counſel would have anſwered, and then let him to tell his Anſwer in French.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: If that be liked better, let it be ſo. Mr. Craven, can you tell the ſubſtance of the Evidence that this Gentlemen hath given?

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: No, I cannot, his Evidence has been ſo long, and ſo many croſs Queſtions have been asked.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: I would ſpare your time—

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: But this is the way to ſpend our time.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: I know your Lordſhip does not value time in ſuch a caſe as this is, but you would have the Truth found out.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You muſt repeat, firſt, the diſcourſe you had with Count Conningsmark.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: My Lord, we will reduce it to two or three Queſtions. Mr. Craven, will you pleaſe to ask him what diſcourſe he had with Count Conningsmark.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: He ſays, the diſcourſe he had with Count Conningsmark about the Polander, was, that he came over as a Groom to ſerve him to look after his Horſes; that he had occaſion for ſeveral Engliſh Horſes, and Engliſh Servants to look after them as Grooms; and among the reſt of his Grooms, he intended the Polander ſhould be one, to dreſs his Horſes after the German way.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: So far he goes as to that, That the Polander came over to ſerve the Count.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, does not he tell you, the Count had a purpoſe to buy Horſes here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: He ſays, there was a diſcourſe about Bills of Exchange of 7000 Piſtols to buy Horſes.

sp.speaker: Sir. Fr. Win.
sp.p: Pray then will you ask him, what diſcourſe he had with Count Conningsmark about the death of Mr. Thynne, and what the Conſequences in Law might be.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: My Lord, he ſays, that the diſcourſe with Count Conningsmark, concerning the Swediſh Agent, was, That in caſe he ſhould ask Satisfaction of Mr. Thynne, for the Affronts that he had given him, not underſtanding the Cuſtoms of the Nation, if he ſhould call him to account, what prejudice it might be to him; for he did not hear, he ſays, that Count Conningsmark deſigned any thing, or reſolved upon killing him, or any thing of that nature; but whether if he ſhould call him to account, what the Laws of England might be.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Call John Wright.

sp.speaker: Sir N. Johnſon.
sp.p: My Lord, the Count deſires to know if he may be permitted to make his Defence againſt theſe Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: No, he is not to make his Defence now. But pray tell him if my Lord have a deſire to ask any Queſtions of this witneſs, he may ask what he pleaſes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: North. Let the Queſtion be put to the Interpreter, that we may know what the Queſtion is before the Witneſs gives an Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Graven.
sp.p: He askes him if he has not ſeen him oftner in his Lodging undreſſed than dreſſed? And whether he was not to take Phyſick from his Phyſician.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I do not remember that in all the time, I ſaw Count Conningsmark, I ſaw him dreſſed four times in his Coat, I cannot ſay I remember three times in all. The firſt time when he came he was in a Campaign Coat; but all the time he was in his Lodging, as I remember, he was in his Night-Gown and Cap. As to the other part of his Queſtion, whether I heard that he took Phyſick? I ſay this, When I ſaw Count Conningsmark firſt at his Lodging; when I came to him, on the Sunday Evening, I was told the Count was in Bed: It was late, but I ventured to go into his Room, and ſat a quarter of an hour there; and afterwards the Doctor came in, Dr. Frederick, I ſaw him oftentimes at his Lodging; and at the ſame time the young Count was ſick of an Ague: and when he came one Evening to ſee the young Count, I asked him what was the Diſtemper the Count had? the Doctor anſwered me, that he had not told any Body that the Count was ſick, or what he was ſick of, but he hoped in God in a ſhort time he would be recovered.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: He askes him if he gave him any poſitive order, that he ſhould go of any Meſſage to the Swediſh Envoy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: This I have anſwered before, and I ſay now, If this diſcourſe that I had with the Swediſh Envoy, turn to the Lord Count Conningsmark's prejudice, it would grate upon my Conſcience all my life: Count Conningsmark never gave me any poſiſitive Order to carry any Meſſage; but I did gather, by his diſcourſe, that the Count might be deſirous to know the Envoy's Opinion about this Queſtion; and therefore I thought the Count deſiring it, I would do it to pleaſe him, rather than by Order. But I do not know that ever the Count had a mind to give me ſuch an Order, but I did it voluntarily.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: In plain Engliſh, Did he ever direct you to go to the Swediſh Envoy?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: No, my Lord, he never did direct me.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Baron.
sp.p: How came you to chuſe a Forreigner to know what the Laws of England are?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: I thought it would pleaſe the Count to know his Opinion.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Bar.
sp.p: But how came you to chuſe a Forreigner, I ask?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: He has been 19 Years here in England, and ſure he ſhould know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: My Lord, he asks him, if ever he told him that he had a deſign to fight Mr. Thynne, or do him any Prejudice, or ſend him a Challenge?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I am upon my Oath, and this I ſay, I ſpeake it before God and the Court, Count Conningsmark did never tell me that he had any mind, or did reſolve to call Eſq Thynne any ways to account.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Call John Wright. (who ſtood up, and was Sworn.)

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: We ſhall ask him but a Queſtion or two, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray tell me the time when this Polander came into England, that man at the Bar.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: He came the 10th day of this Month.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray what Ship did he come in? where did you firſt meet with him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: Here in Town.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Where was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: At the Croſs-Keys in Throgmorton-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray when you firſt ſaw him; what did he ask you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: He asked me where Count Conningsmark's Lodgings were? I told him, I thought he was at Oxford, I meant the young Gentleman, for I did not know the other was in Town; but I went and enquired, and they told me, it was at Faubert's Academy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Whither went you with the Polander then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: I went to my Lord's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What Lord?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: The young Count's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Well, and what then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: And I came to Mr. Hanſon, and he did deliver a Letter to Mr. Hanſon, and I ſtayed there about half an hour, or there-abouts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: Upon Friday, the 10th day of this month.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: How long was Mr. Hanſon and the Polander together?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: About half an hour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What ſaid Hanſon to him in your preſence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: Mr. Hanſon ſaid nothing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was there any thing ſaid about going back, and paying his Lodging, and coming back?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: Mr. Hanſon came down to me, and told me, he was glad to ſee me, and bid me take the Polander back with me, and bring him to him to morrow betimes, for he muſt diſpatch him about his Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Then he ſaid nothing to the Polander?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: No, but to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Well, what did you do the next morning?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: I came to him the next morning to this Polander, and he took his things with him, which was a Sea-bed that he had, and a Gun with a Wheel-lock, and ſome other things.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: And whither did you bring him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: I brought him to the upper end of the Hay-market, Monſieur Faubert's School.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: To what place did you come in the morning, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wright.
sp.p: Sir, if it pleaſe you, I brought him within a Door or two of Mr. Faubert's the Horſe-maſter, that teaches to ride the great Horſe; for he did deſire that we might go to an Houſe hard by, becauſe he would not carry his carriage to my Lord, he had a Sea-bed, a Portmantle, a Gun, and other things; and ſo I brought him to an Houſe, and there I called for a Pot of Ale; and he put down his things and went out, I thought he had gone to make water, but within a little while after returns again, and Mr. Hanſon comes in with him; he asked me why I did not come ſooner? I told him, I had ſome other Buſineſs, I was with ſome French Merchants to look upon ſome Goods. So he bid the Pole pay me for my trouble, and take up his things, and go along with him; and he did do ſo, and I never ſaw the Pole afterwards.

sp.speaker: L. Cb. J.
sp.p: You that are the Interpreters, repeat what he bath ſaid to the Jury. (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: We have done with this man, the uſe we make of him, is to follow this Polander, and we ſhall bring him to the Count by and by. Call Dr. Frederick Harder. (who was ſworn.)

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: The Doctor underſtands Engliſh, don't he?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Yes, we are told he does.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: How long have you known the Count that ſtands there at the Bar?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I have known him a good while; it may be this four or five Years; I have known him four or five Years.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: How long have you known Captain Vratz?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: About a Year and a half, or two Years.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Was my Lord and Capt. Vratz acquainted then?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was he in employment under my Lord? was he in the Counts Service?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: He was with the Count, but whether he was his Companion, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Did he live with the Count?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Did Capt. Vratz, when the Count came laſt over into England, come over with him.

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, by my knowledg.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: Do you know it or not?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Capt. Vratz came to me, and told me, my Lord deſired to ſpeak with me, and I went with him to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Was that the firſt Meſſage you received from the Count?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: How long was that ago?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: The ſame day the Morocco Embaſſador did exerciſe in Hide-Park.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: How long is that ago?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: About a month ago.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: What, was that his firſt Lodging after he came laſt into England?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: It was in the Hay-market.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: Was it a corner Houſe, as the other Witneſs ſaith, or not?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was the Count a private Lodger there?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: He lay in his Bed when I came to him; he came as a Traveller privately.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Did he go by his own Name, or another Name?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: No Body did queſtion him about his Name, but when I did come to him, I did diſcourſe him about his Body.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray Sir, thus; you went often to viſit him, pray did you enquire for him by his own Name, or any other Name?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: He deſired that he might be private, becauſe he was to take ſome Medicines, and he would not have it known.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Now Sir, I would ask you, did you obſerve him to be in any Diſguiſe? Did he wear a Perriwig, or how?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: He had a Perriwig.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was it a fair Perriwig, or what colour?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: It was brown or black.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Sir, was he in a diſguiſe, or no?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: He had his own Clothes, but he had a Perriwig.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Pray what Name did he go by, his right Name, or any particular Name?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: In the firſt beginning I gave him no Name, but ſaid he to me, If any Body ask you about me, I would not be known; for if they know that I lie privately thus, they will think I ail ſome ill Diſtemper, therefore I would have you call me by the Name of Carlo Cuski.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Were you with him, pray Sir, upon the Sunday Morning that Mr. Thynne was murdered?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I cannot certainly tell, but I was with him in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Pray call your ſelf to mind, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I cannot certainly tell.

sp.speaker: Sir. Fr. Win.
sp.p: What time were you with him in the Evening?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: At nine a Clock at night, or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Did you receive any Letter from Capt. Vratz at any time?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I did, upon Saturday morning, the Saturday before Mr. Thynne was murdered.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Have you that Letter about you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: What was in the Letter?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: He deſired me to go to the Count, who had a deſire to ſpeak with me. I came there and had ſome ſpeech with him about his Indiſpoſition; I told him he had better ſtay till next day before he took Phyſick, becauſe it was cold Weather. And after that went with the Polander to my Lodging, and the Captains man came in, and then ſaid, here is a man that will direct you to Capt. Vratz Lodging; which I did not know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, you ſay you went to the Count, Did you ſhew the Count that Letter from Capt. Vrats, or no?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: The Count ſaw it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Then hear a little, When was it you ſhew'd the Letter to the Count? Was it Saturday or Sunday?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: It was Saturday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Now, was the Polander then in the Count's Lodgings, or no?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harde.
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was there any diſcourſe about him then?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I had never ſeen him in my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: But was there any with the Count?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder,
sp.p: No, not at all.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Then, upon your Oath I ask you once more, Was the Polander ever in Company with you and my Lord at any time?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Upon the Sunday, upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Nor the Saturday evening?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: No, I have not ſeen him ſince that morning when the Captains man took him along with him to his Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray how came the Polander into your company on Saturday morning?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I had him from my Lords that morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Then my Lord and the Polander were together?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: No, they were not together.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Was the Polander in my Lord's Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, the Polander was below ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: And did you take him from the Lodging?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: How long did he continue with you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Not at all, I went home with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Had you no diſcourſe with him?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: No, none at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Where did you part with him?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I brought him to my Houſe; and when he came in a Doors, the Captain's man being there, I told him there was a man would ſhew him the Captains Lodgings; and he took him away along with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: You ſay, the Captains Man had the Polander from you; pray name that man.

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I cannot tell his Name.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Was his name Berg?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I believe it was.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: You ſay you delivered a Letter from Capt. Vratz on Saturday morning to the Count?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Did the Count read the Letter, and tell you the Contents of it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: No, it was not ſealed.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Did not you know the Contents of it then?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Pray, when you delivered the Letter from Capt. Vratz to the Count, what did the Count ſay to you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: The Letter was not written to the Count, but it was writ to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: What was the reaſon that you ſhewed it to him then?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I received a Letter from Capt. Vratz, that the Count deſired to ſpeak with me; and afterwards I was deſired to direct this Man, the Polander, to Captain Vratz; and ſo I directed him to Capt. Vratz, and nothing more I know.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Well, Sir, one thing more and I have done with you, for you will not, I ſee, give a reaſonable Anſwer; pray, when the Polander came along with you from the Counts, did you obſerve he had any thing about him?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: He had a great Campaign Coat.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Did he ſeem to have any thing under it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: He had a Portmantle under it, I think, or ſome ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: My Lord, the Count deſires to ask him ſome Queſtions.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: Let him ask what Queſtions he will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: My Lord, he asks him whether he does not remember, when he firſt came to Town, he had not his Body full of Spots?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harden.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, when he came from Tangier, he had ſpots over all his Breaſt; and it was feared they might get up higher towards his Neck, and indanger him very much.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: He ſays, If my Lord pleaſes, he will ſhew it openly.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: No, there is no need of that Goctor. Did you give him Phyſick for that?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, for that I did adminiſter Phyſick to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: He ſays, my Lord, he over-heated himſelf in riding to Tangier, thinking to do the King and the Nation Service, and the Heat broke out in ſpots over his Breſt.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: The Doctor knows nothing of that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: He asks, Whether the Doctor was not deſired by him to cure him; whether he did not tell him he would cure him of thoſe Spots?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: He deſired me to adminiſter Phyſick unto him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: He ſays, he went to Strasburgh, and when he came back, he was in the ſame condition he was in before; and he asks whether the Doctor did not undertake to cure him?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, I did adminiſter Phyſick unto him; and this my own man can teſtify and be witneſs of; becauſe my Lord bid me take care that he might be private, for he would not have it known that he did take Phyſick; but I told my man, ſaid I, 'tis my Lord Conningsmark, and therefore pray take care of him, and ſee that the Phyſick be made very well up.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: You ſeem to intimate, as if he lay private to take Phyſick, pray let me ask you this Queſtion, Did you give him Phyſick all this time?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Not always purging Phyſick, but ſome ſort of Phyſick all the time?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: What every night and morning?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, every day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: The Count deſires to ask him where he was that unhappy day this Buſineſs was done?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I found him that day ill, lying down upon the Bed, I asked him how his Phyſick had worked; he told me he was afraid he had got ſome cold; and indeed I found him very much diſordered, and I went home and fetched him ſome Phyſick to take that night.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: By the Oath you have taken, was there any other occaſion, or had you any other diſcourſe with him, when you came on the Sunday night, but concerning his Phyſick?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: My Lord, I will tell you the Truth; I never heard the Count ſpeak any word in my life, that he had any concern, or deſign of any quarrel at all, nor any diſcourſe, but about the adminiſtration of his Phyſick.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: Let me ask you this Queſtion, for they deſire it here, What was the occaſion? And whether you know the occaſion why my Lord altered his Lodgings ſo often?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: The firſt occaſion was this, Becauſe it was in the Hay-market; and his Man ſaid it would be quickly known if he did continue there; ſo he would take another Lodging, which was in Buperts-ſtreet, and there he lodged three days; but the Chimney did ſo ſmoke, that my Lord could not ſtay, becauſe he could have no Fire in his Chamber, and the weather was very cold, for it did Snow, and therefore I told my Lord, it was not ſo proper for taking of Phyſick: Thereupon he deſired me to take him another Lodging in Queen-ſtreet, which I did look about for, but it was not ready, ſo he had a Lodging taken for him in St. Martins-lane, where he lodged till he went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, the Phyſick that you gave the Count, did it require his keeping within doors? might not he walk abroad with it, upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: It did require him to keep in.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray then, how comes it to paſs that the Count ſo ſuddenly could go by Water to Graveſend?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I do not know what was done afterwards.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: I would ask you one Queſtion, and I would fain have you give me a fair anſwer to it, What became of the Letter that Capt. Vratz writ to you, and you ſhewed it to the Count.

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: It remained there upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Win.
sp.p: Did not you keep your own Letter?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: It was not of any Concern.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: If the Letter were written to you, it is not ſo long ſince, but you can tell us the Contents of it; pray what were the Contents?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: Can you remember what were the Contents?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: He deſired me to go to Count Conningsmark, who would ſpeak with me; and that I would give his man an Anſwer when I came from him.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: But what were you to go to the Count to do?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Nothing, but the Count diſcourſed to me about his own Body and Indiſpoſition.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: But Capt. Vratz was no Phyſician; why ſhould he ſend you a Letter to talk about Phyſick?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: It was nothing but my Lord would ſpeak with me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: We need not trouble our ſelves with this Fellow, he confeſſes he found the Polander in the Count's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Withins.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me ask you, Who was with the Count on Sunday night?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Mr. Hanſon was there, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Withins.
sp.p: Who elſe?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: The Captain came in, and went out again.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: What time of night was it that Vratz came in to the Count?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: It was at the ſame time that I was with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: That he ſwears to be about nine a Clock; Was it after Mr. Thynne was killed?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: We had not heard it.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Sir, was it nine of the Clock?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: You ſay you found the Polanderat the Count's Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, upon Saturday morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Then he came along with you from the Count's Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, to my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: And you parted with him there?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, the Captains man took him away with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: That was Berg, wa'nt it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes.

div.p: Then this Evidence was interpreted to the Jury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: He deſires the Jury ſhould know what the Doctor ſaid about his Sickneſs.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: Let it be repeated to them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: He deſires to know whether he may not ſpeak it in French himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: No, the Interpreter muſt do it; (which was done.) My Lord, would you ask any more Queſtions of the Doctor?

sp.speaker: Count Conn.
sp.p: No more Queſtions but them I have asked.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Call Thomas Howgood. (who was ſworn.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray, did you ſell any Sword to the Count?

sp.speaker: Mr. Howgood.
sp.p: I ſold a Sword to the Governor, a broad Horſeman's Sword.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Howgood.
sp.p: On Saturday was fortnight.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What time was it that he beſpoke it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Howgood.
sp.p: He beſpoke it half an hour after ſix at night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What did he ſay to you when he bought it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Howgood.
sp.p: He ſaid he would call for it about eight a Clock at night, when he came from the Play.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What kind of Sword was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Howgood.
sp.p: An Horſeman's Sword, as broad as two fingers, ſuch as the Gentlemen of the Guards wear.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: When he came for the Sword, what ſaid he?

sp.speaker: Mr. Howgood.
sp.p: He was angry it was not done, and I told him that I would ſend it to him quickly.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Where was it ſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Howgood.
sp.p: To the Governor's Lodgings at the Academy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, we will call ſeveral Perſons that were privy to the concealing of this Gentleman, that can give you a better account, Richard Hays and Robert French.

div.p: (Robert French appeared, and was ſworn.)

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: Pray, will you tell my Lord what you know of the Count's concealing himſelf, and changing his Habit.

sp.speaker: Mr. French.
sp.p: I never ſaw him, my Lord, before I came here in Court, but it ſeems he did lodg in my Houſe three or four days.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: How long is it ſince?

sp.speaker: Mr. French.
sp.p: Between three weeks and a month ago, juſt ten days before the Murder.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Win.
sp.p: What Name did he go by then?

sp.speaker: Mr. French.
sp.p: I did not know his Name.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Who uſed to reſort to him at that time?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: You ſay, Sir, you ſaw him not, what company did come to him?

sp.speaker: Mr. French.
sp.p: I did not ſee him indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Pray did Capt. Vratz come to him to your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. French.
sp.p: He lodged with him all the time.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: You ſay you know Capt. Vratz was there?

sp.speaker: Mr. French.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Did Dr. Harder uſe to come to him?

sp.speaker: Mr. French.
sp.p: Yes, ſeveral times a day.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: What Name did he enquire for him by?

sp.speaker: Mr. French.
sp.p: The Doctor took the Lodging, and it was for a ſtranger, I heard no Name at all.

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: My Lord deſires to know, whether you did not ſuſpect he took Phyſick in the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. French.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe the Doctor did give you an account of that, I don't know that he did.

sp.speaker: Interpret.
sp.p: Did not your Maid know of any ſuch thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. French.
sp.p: My Maid is here, ſhe will give you an account.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Call Ann Prince; (who was ſworn) Pray do you acquaint my Lord what you know of Count Conningsmark; whether ever you ſaw him at your Maſters Houſe in the Hay market?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Yes, he lodged there.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: He came thither laſt Friday was a month.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: How long did he ſtay there?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Till VVedneſday.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: At that time, who uſed to frequent his Company?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I know no Body but the Doctor that uſed to come to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: What Name did he go by?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: No Name at all as I know of; they did not ask for him by any Name.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Did the Captain uſe to come to him?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: Her Maſter ſays he did lie there.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Yes, he uſed to lodg there.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Did the Captain give him any Phyſick?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: No, but the Doctor did.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: He only asks a merry Quſtion.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: But we are now upon the Life and Death of a man, pray let us have thoſe Queſtions asked that are ſerious, not ſuch light things as are permitted in ordinary Caſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, we will call Francis VVatts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: Maid, my Lord asks, whether he did not take a Vomit in your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

div.p: Then Francis Watts was ſworn.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: How old is the Child?

sp.speaker: Fr. VVatts.
sp.p: Fifteen Years old laſt Chriſtmaſs.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Baron.
sp.p: Ask him whether he underſtands what an Oath is?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thynne.
sp.p: He was ſworn before the King and Council.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Baron.
sp.p: If he were ſworn before the Council, he may give Evidence here ſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: Were you at the Counts Service at any time.

sp.speaker: VVatts.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: How long?

sp.speaker: VVatts.
sp.p: I was with him eleven days; I came to him upon the Friday.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: How long was it before the Death of Mr. Thynne?

sp.speaker: VVatts.
sp.p: I think it was ten days before the Death of Mr. Thynne.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. VVin.
sp.p: What was your Employment with him?

sp.speaker: VVatts.
sp.p: His Boy to wait upon him.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Did you lye in the ſame Lodging?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: No, at my Fathers.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winn.
sp.p: What was the Agreement between your Father and the Count?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Six pence a day, and my diet.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winn.
sp.p: What Company did you obſerve came to the Count's Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: That Gentleman there in the black Perriwig.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winn.
sp.p: Was he often with your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes, every day.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winn.
sp.p: How many Lodgings had he while you were with him?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Three: one in the Hay-market, and one in Rupert-ſtreet, and then the laſt in St. Martins.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Thus Child, Do you remember the time of killing Mr. Thynne?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Were you in your Maſter's Service then?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Who was in your Maſter's Company that morning before Mr. Thynne was killed?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I came up, as I uſed to do in the morning, to my Maſter, and he aked me what was the matter with the buſtle in the Street? and I told him ſome body was taken upon ſuſpicion for killing Eſq Thynne.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Wynn.
sp.p: That was on the Monday morning; but the Sunday morning before, what Company did you obſerve there then?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I cannot tell any thing exactly of the Sunday morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Wynn.
sp.p: Was Captain Vratz there?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I can't exactly remember.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: What time in the Evening was it reported Mr. Thynne was kill'd?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: About eight a clock.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Can you tell who brought the firſt news?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: One of my Lady Seymour's Maids, who was telling the People of it below.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Did you obſerve any body come to your Maſter's Lodgings afterwards?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Pray who came?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: That Gentleman in the black Periwigg.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray in what Habit was he, and how came he in?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: He came in a great Coat; I can't tell whether it was Cloath or Chamblet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams,
sp.p: And what, did he ſpeak to any Body, or go ſtrait up?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: No, he ſpoke to no Body, but went ſtrait up Stairs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Did he go up to your Maſter's Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes, I believe ſo, but I ſtay'd below in the Shop.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: How long did you ſtay in the Shop?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I ſtay'd there about half an Hour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Did you leave him there?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Did he continue there all the time that you were in the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What time did you go away?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: About three Quarters of an Hour after that Gentleman came in.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Withins.
sp.p: Do you remember you had any diſcourſe with the Count, about riding on Sundays.

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: He asked me on Sunday in the Fore-noon, whether People were ſuffered to ride about the Streets on Horſe-back on Sundays.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: This was that Sunday morning, was it?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes: he asked if they might be ſuffered to ride about the Streets on Sunday, I told him yes, before Sermon time and after Sermon time.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Win.
sp.p: About what time of the day was it that he had this diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: About ten or eleven a Clock.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Are you ſure it was Sunday?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Then I ask you another Queſtion; upon Sunday Morning or any other time, do you remember that the Polander was with the Count your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: He came in on the Saturday morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was he in the Company or Preſence of the Count?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I was above ſtairs when he came in.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: What do you know of any Sword that was delivered to him?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Upon the Sunday Morning there was a Sword brought to my Maſter's Lodgings, and my Maſter's man took it of me, and carried it up ſtairs, and this man, the Polander, afterwards had it below ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: When was this Sword brought to your Maſter's houſe?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: It was on the Sunday morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What, the Cutler brought the Sword?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: No, it was ſent by a Porter from Mr. Hanſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What Room was it carryed into when it was brought?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I think I did not carry it up: Yes truly, now I remember, I did, and delivered it to my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray what did the Count ſay to you?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I asked him if there needed an Anſwer of the Note I carryed with it, and he ſaid no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: To whom was that Sword delivered afterwards?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: It was brought down, and afterwards this Polander had it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: That man there?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: You ſay that the Sword was given to the Polander: Pray ſpeak that the Jury may hear. Who brought down the Sword?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I ſaw it in the Polander's keeping when it was below, but I cannot ſay who brought it down.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Where did the Polander dine on Saturday?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: He dined with my Maſter's Man and I on Saturday.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Where did he lye that Night? At whoſe Chamber?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: At our Lodgings in the Garret, in my Maſter's Man's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: What day was this, do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Saturday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: When the Polander had the Sword, do you remember any Boots that he had under his Arm.

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes, he had Boots under his Arm.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: And he had the Sword with him when he went away?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Had he any Coat?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes, a new Coat.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: Well, I ask you once more, what time of day was it that he went away with the Sword and the Boots?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: It was in the Fore-noon.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: VVhat day of the Week?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Sunday morning.

sp.speaker: L. Chief. Juſt.
sp.p: Ay, but your Doctor that you examined before, ſays, the Polander went away with him, and he was not there on Sunday Morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. VVinn.
sp.p: It is true, my Lord, it was too tender a point for the Doctor, he lyes under ſome Suſpicion; and 'tis proximus ardet with him.

sp.speaker: L. Chief. Juſt.
sp.p: Well call him again: Look you Doctor, you were asked before, and now you are asked again, were you at Count Coningſmark's Lodgings on the Sunday Morning?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I cannot certainly tell.

sp.speaker: L. Chief. Juſt.
sp.p: When did you ſee the Polander at the Count's Lodgings, and whether was it on Sunday morning?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: On Sunday Morning I did not ſee him. The only time was when I fetched him from my Lords, I have not ſeen him before nor ſince.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Then call up the Boy again. VVhere did the Polander dine on Saturday?

sp.speaker: VVatts.
sp.p: He dined with me and my Maſter's Man.

sp.speaker: L. Chief. Juſt.
sp.p: VVhere?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Below, in the Kitchin of our Lodgings.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Where lay the Polander that night?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: He lay in our Garret.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When went he from your Maſter's Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: On Sunday morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Had he an old Coat or a new Coat upon him?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: He had a new Coat.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was the Doctor with him?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes, the Doctor went away with him.

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I have not ſeen the Polander above once in my Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Win.
sp.p: But were you at the Count's on Sunday morning, or no, I ask you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I do not know whether it was Saturday or Sunday.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But when you fetched him away, was it Saturday or Sunday morning?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder
sp.p: My Lord, I can't very well remember.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Had the Polander a Sword when you went away with him?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: I cannot poſitively ſay, but (as Travellers commonly have) he might have a Sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Win.
sp.p: Now come to your ſelf, and deal honeſtly, for you are upon your Oath; I ask you, friend, this, You ſay he might have a Sword, do you remember a pair of Boots?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: No, I do not.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Win.
sp.p: Do you remember the Coat he had uppermoſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Harder.
sp.p: Yes, he had ſomething under his Coat, but I don't know it was Boots.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Baron.
sp.p: Had he a Buff-coat under his Campaigne?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Withins.
sp.p: Let me ask you one Queſtion, young man, Do you remember you ſaw any Muſquetoon in your Maſter's Lodging?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I did ſee a Gun there.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Withins.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I ſaw it upon Saturday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: The Muſquetoon or Gun that was in your Maſters Lodgings, was it that which was bought by the Polander, or no?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I can't tell that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was it a long Piece or a ſhort Piece?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: It was not a ſhort Piece.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Did the Polander take it away with him?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: No, not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Now, young man, I would ask you as to Monday morning: About what time on Monday morning did you come to your Maſters Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: It was between 7 and 8 a clock, a little after ſeven.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What condition was he in? was he in bed, or up?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: He was up.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What was he doing? was he packing up?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Not that I ſee.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Win.
sp.p: It was when he asked you about the Hubbub in the ſtreet; pray tell what he ſaid to you.

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: He asked me what was the matter with the buſtle in the ſtreet? and I told him that ſome were taken that had killed Eſq Thynne; and I told him all the ſtory as near as I could: He asked me when Eſq Thynne was murdered? I told him the Night before, but I did not mind any thing that was done: But as I went down ſtairs, I met with a ſtranger, and he went up ſtairs, but I never ſaw my Maſter after, till he was taken.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra Win.
sp.p: Did he ask you what Mr. Thynne was?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes, and I told him I heard he was a man of a great Eſtate, and well-beloved, and that the Duke of Monmouth was in the Coach but a little before, and if he had not gone out, he had been kill'd too.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Win.
sp.p: VVhat ſaid the Count to you, when you told him Mr. Thynne was well-beloved?

sp.speaker: VVatts.
sp.p: He ſaid nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Can you remember who it was came to your Maſter then?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: I know the Man if I ſee him again.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Do you know his Name?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: No, I do not know his Name.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Were any of your Maſter's Goods carried away then?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What Goods were carried away then?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Two Portmanteaus.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Who carried them away?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: My Father carried them away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What time was it?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Between 8 and 9 of the Clock.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: It was time to be gone. How parted you and your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: The Stranger did come in, and I never ſaw my Maſter afterwards.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: What, did your Maſter take no Leave, nor ſay any thing to you?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: What kind of Periwigg had he when he went away?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: He had a black Periwigg.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: What Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: A light coloured Suit, with gold Buttons.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Baron.
sp.p: Will the Count ask the Boy any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Mr. Craven.
sp.p: Did you ſee the Gun in the Room after the Polander was gone?

sp.speaker: Watts.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: 'Tis very plain, that this Gun was none of the Gun that did this Miſchief, but the Gun the Polander brought over from beyond Sea.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra Winn.
sp.p: Call the Boy's Father, Thomas Watts (who was ſworn) How long have you known the Count?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: I do not know him but as I have ſeen him.

sp.speaker: Sir Fra. Winn.
sp.p: Were you employed to carry any thing for him?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: Two or three times I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: VVhen were you laſt employed by him?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: The Morrow after the Murder was committed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What Time in the morning was it?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: It was between 8 and 9 of the Clock in the morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What was it you did for him?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: I carried a Portmanteau, and a Portmanteau Trunck, and ſome other things.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Where were you directed to deliver theſe?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: His Man told me they were to go to Windſor.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Well, tell the whole Story.

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: He bid me carry them to Charing Croſs, that they might be put into the Coach there. But when he came to Charing Croſs, a Coach-man and he had ſome Words, and he bid him open his Boot, and then he took the things from me, and put them into the Coach.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Who was it that told you they were to go to Windſor?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: It was his Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: I would ask you, Sir, when was the firſt time you knew the Count?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: It was ten or eleven days before.

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Winning.
sp.p: What was the occaſion that brought you acquainted with him?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: I was Dr. Frederick's Porter, and he ſent me to carry ſome things to the Count.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was it your Son that waited upon him?

sp.speaker: T. VVats.
sp.p: Yes. For when I brought the things, they ſaid they had forgot to give me a Sword which I was to carry with the things; and I ſaid, that I had a Boy that I would ſend, and I did ſo, and ſo they took a Liking to the Boy.

sp.speaker: Mr. VVilliams.
sp.p: What was the Agreement for your Son's Service?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: Six pence a Day, and his Victuals.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: What was the man's name (as you remember) that gave you the things to carry to the Coach, which were ſaid to go to Windſor?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: I can't tell his Name.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: He that pinched and puſhed you back, and took the things from you and put them into the Coach?

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Did you ſee the Count that Morning?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: No, I did not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Have you been laboured and ſought to by any body to conceal your Boy, that he ſhould not be brought at this Tryal?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Had you no endeavours uſed with you about it?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Did no body ſpeak of any ſuch thing to you?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Did any Merchant or any body ſend to you about this Body, to take him into Service?

sp.speaker: T. Watts.
sp.p: There was a Merchant that would have helped the Boy to a place on Saturday laſt, but the Perſons that would have procured it were about it a good while ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Call Derick Raynes, and Richard Chappel.
(who were Sworn and Raynes ſtood up.)
When did you ſee the Count, the Priſoner at the Bar?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: On Monday in the Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What time was it in the Afternoon?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: In the Evening.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Where was it?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: At my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Where is that?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: At Rotherith.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: How came the Count to your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: I know not, I was not at home when he came.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray when you ſaw him, had he his own Hair or a Perriwig, or how was he habited?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: He had black Hair then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: How long did he continue at your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: From Monday till Thurſday Morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was he privately there or publickly?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: He walked up and down the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Win.
sp.p: What Country-man are you?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: I am a Sweed.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: What became of him after Thurſday?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: On Thurſday Morning he took Water and went to Deptford.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: What way did he go, by Boat, or how?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: A Waterman carried him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray what did the Count ſay to you about his coming in a diſguiſe to your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: I knew nothing at all. I came late home, and when I came to know of him what he was, then he told me that he was Count Coningsmark.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What did he ſay to you when you diſcovered that he was the Count? What did he tell you of his buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: He ſaid nothing; but that he was deſirous to go to Graves-End.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Upon your Oath, Sir, did you furniſh him with any Clothes?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: Yes, I lent him a Coat.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: What ſay you to a black Suit?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: The black Suit did not belong to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: What ſay you to a Velvet Cap?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: I helped him to a Coat, Stockings, and Shoes.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Then I ask you, what did he declare to you?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: Why, he did deſire to have thoſe Clothes.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: You are an honeſt man, tell the truth.

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: He declared nothing to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: When you dreſſed him, why did he put on that habit?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: He thought his own Clothes were too cold to go upon the water.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Had he no Clothes before?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: Yes, he had.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: You had the warmer Coat, had you?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Did he deſire you to let him have your Clothes, becauſe he was in trouble?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: He deſired a Coat of me, and a pair of Stockings to keep his Leggs warm, and when he had got them, his own Shoes would not come on, ſo I lent him a pair of Shoes.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: I do ask you, did he declare the reaſon why he would have thoſe Cloathes, was, becauſe he would not be known?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: He ſaid he was afraid of coming into trouble.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Why were you unwilling to tell this?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: Aſſoon as I came to know he was the man, I told him he ſhould not ſtay in my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Win.
sp.p: Did you lend him thoſe Clothes or ſell them?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: I lent him them.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Had you them again?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: No, I had not.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Are you paid for them or no?

sp.speaker: Raynes.
sp.p: No, my Ship lyes at the Key, and I came home late in the Evening, and found him there.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Set up Richard Chappel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: When did you firſt ſee that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: On Thurſday Morning at Ten of the Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: At Rotherith.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: How came you to him? who brought you?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: That Man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What were you to do with him?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: To carry him to Graves-End.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Do you Row in a pair of Oars, or a Sculler?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: A Sculler.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Whither did you carry the Count that day?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: To Deptford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Whither the next day?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: To Greenwich.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: And whither then?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: To Greenhithe, and then the next day to Graves-End.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was he in the ſame Clothes all the while?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: Yes, all the while.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: Were you hired to wait upon him all that time?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: Yes, I was to have 5 s. every 24 hours.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: Was he alone?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: No, this man was with him.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Did he go in the Sculler with him?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: Yes, to Deptford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Well, now we will call the Gentleman that ſeized him at the Water-ſide at Graves-End.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: What did the Count call himſelf? What profeſſion did he tell you he was of?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: He told me he was a Merchant.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Did he ſay he was a Jeweller upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Chappel.
sp.p: Yes, he ſaid he had bought Jewels.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Where is Mr. Gibbons, and Mr. John Kid? who were Sworn and Mr. Kid ſtood up.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p:
Mr. Kid, pray Sir, will you acquaint my Lord and the Jury,
in what Condition you found the Count at Graves-End. Tell the whole ſtory, and ſpeak aloud, that all may hear you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kid.
sp.p: I had ſome Information upon Friday Night of him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Willians.
sp.p: Of whom, and what?

sp.speaker: Mr. Kid.
sp.p: Of the Count where he was. So I made it my Buſineſs to inquire into it. On Saturday in the Afternoon a Gentleman came to me, and gave me certain Information where he thought that Gentleman the Count was. This Gentleman coming to me ſaid, Mr. Thynne is a ſtranger to me, but ſaid he, I would not have Mr. Thynn's Blood lye at my door. This ſame perſon who is put out in the Gazette, I believe, is at a Neighbours houſe of mine. Says he, I deſire you to be private in it, becauſe it may do you a prejudice: ſo we went into a Coach at Charing-Croſs to go to a Juſtice of Peace; I did not know where Sir John Reresby lived, but inquired of Mr. Gibbon's, who told me, but he was not at home, and Mr. Bridgman was not at home; So we went to the Recorder, and there we had a Warrant, and then I came by water to Rotherith, and this ſame Raynes that was Examined, and his Wife where he lay, were gone to Greenwich to carry his Clothes, a grey Suit, and other Clothes that he had left. So going down to Greenwich we called every Boat that was upon the River aboard of us, to know whence they came. And we had taken her Siſter along with us, and ſhe called out her Siſters name Mall Raynes, and her Brothers name Derrick Raynes, and ſo at laſt we got the Boat wherein they were on board us. And we asked the man, what he had done with the Gentleman that lay at his Houſe? he declared, he was gone away he did not know whither. So I went back again to this Gentleman that gave me this firſt Information, who did go to him as a Neighbour, to know whither he was gone, and where he was to be found, and where he would Land. So he declared the particulars, That if we miſſed him that Night, we ſhould have him in the Hope upon Monday Morning, upon a Veſſel that was to be cleared on Monday Morning. So upon Sunday Night coming to Graveſ-end about 8 or 9 a Clock, or there abouts, there he landed. There were 13 or 14 Swedes at the ſame Houſe where he was to Land. So we thought it convenient to take him at his firſt landing, for fear of further danger. So I ſtay'd at the Red Lyon Back-Stayres, and he landed at the Fore-ſtayres where the Watermen were. As ſoon as he was laid hold of, I came to him, ſaid I, your Lordſhip ſhall not want for any thing that is convenient. He deſired to know, whether I knew him? I told him; Yes, and that his name was Count Coningsmarke. That is my Name, ſays he; I do not deny it. So the Maior came and the Custom-Houſe Officers Searched him? and found nothing at all of any Arms about him. He deſired he might be uſed like a Gentleman, and ſo he was, for there was no abuſe given to him, as I know of. Coming up the River, the moſt of my diſcourſe was about Martial Affairs; a Serjeant that had the Command of a File of Muſqueteers, which the Deputy-Governour ſent to guard the Count to White-Hall, a Gentleman ſitting there by me was asking me concerning Mr. Thynne's Murder; I told him, that I was at New-gate on Friday, and there I ſaw thoſe that had done that barbarous Fact. With that, my Lord asked, what Lodgings there were in New-gate. And whether the Captain had a good Lodging? I told him a very good one. He asked me, whether he confeſſed any thing? I told him he had confeſſed ſome particulars; And ſaid I, 'tis the moſt barbarous thing that ever was done. Certainly, ſays my Lord, this Mr. Thynne muſt have Correſpondence and Commerce with ſome Lady that this Captain knew, that belonged to the Court, or he would never have done it. As for the Polander, I told him, that he had confeſſed, he wept mightily. With that my Lord ſeemed very much concerned, and took up his Clothes and bit them, and ſat awhile up, but was very much diſcompoſed, and then deſired to lye down.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: That was, when you told him, the Polander had confeſſed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Kid.
sp.p: Yes; my Lord was mightily altered in his Countenance.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Did you at the firſt time that you ſeized him charge him with the Murder?

sp.speaker: Mr. Kid.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Was he in a Black Perriwig?

sp.speaker: Mr. Kid.
sp.p: His Cap fell off, and his Perriwig, juſt as I came to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Set up Mr. Gibbons. Pray will you tell what paſſed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gibbons.
sp.p: My Lord, Aſſoon as ever he came to ſhore, I walked by him, and gave him a little kind of a juſtle, and my reaſon was, to ſee whether he had not a black Coat under his Campaign: I walked cloſe to him juſt in this manner, as he walked along, ſo he turns about again, and went down to the Water ſide, and asked the Water-men, Watermen, Have you ſtowed your Boat? he anſwered, Yes; Then come away ſaid he; ſo ſoon as he came back again, I catched him faſt hold by the Arm, and the firſt word he ſaid to me was, What do you come to Rob me? ſaid I, my Lord, you are my Priſoner, and I told him I was the King's Meſſenger that had waited there ſeveral days for him; holding of him very hard whether, that was the occaſion of it, or the Waterman that were on the other ſide of him, he dropped down his Sword between his Leggs; but when I named his Name, he gave a little ſtart and his Perriwig dropped off of his Face. We went up the Street to the Mayor, and the People crowding about us were very rude and very rugged, and he deſired he might be well uſed. We did all we could to keep the People from him; we went up to the Mayor's Houſe, and when we came there, I deſired he might be ſearched, whether he had any Arms; He ſaid, he had none, and there was none.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: When you had the Cuſtody of him, whither did you carry him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gibbons.
sp.p: We carried him to the Mayor's Houſe, and after we removed him from his Houſe to an Inn.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: What did you do the next Day?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gibbons.
sp.p: We ſtayed there about ſome 2 or 3 Hours. After an hour or half an hours time, near upon an hour, my Lord came to me, and asked me my Name; and he ſaid, the reaſon was, that after his Trouble was over, he would give me thanks for my Civility to him. Captain Sinkleer, who ſtood by, gave him my Name before I could, that it was Gibbons. Yes ſaid I, my Name is Gibbons, and I belong to the Duke of Monmouth: why ſays he, the Duke of Monmouth has no Command now, and therefore how could I take him by his Order? My Lord, ſaid I, I do not apprehend you by his Order; you have killed a very good Friend of mine, and had not Providence ordered it otherwiſe, you had like to have killed a more particular Friend, and a Maſter: So my Lord he ſeemed to be very ſorry at that; but ſays he, I don't think they would have done any harm to the Duke of Monmouth.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: What elſe did he ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gibbons.
sp.p: I think I have told you all that is Material.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winn.
sp.p: Were you in the Boat at any time, and gave him any Account of the Man's having Confeſſed; what did he ſay to it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gibbons.
sp.p: Sir, I was not there, nor I did not come up in the ſame Boat with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Did he mention any thing about a ſtain to his Blood?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gibbons.
sp.p: I ask your pardon, he did ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What did he ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gibbons.
